title: DATS 6450 ‚Äì Reinforcement Learning
text:
Course Description
The aim of this course is to provide a comprehensive understanding of the reinforcement learning framework. The course will explore the key distinctions between reinforcement learning and other artificial intelligence learning paradigms, delve into relevant industry applications, and examine both classical and deep learning approaches. Additionally, the course will cover the taxonomy of reinforcement learning and offer hands-on experience through practical implementations using OpenAI Gymnasium and other learning environments.
The classical approach will focus on learning methods designed to find optimal solutions in tabular environments, whereas the deep learning approach will tackle the challenge of finding approximate optimal solutions in large or continuous environments through the use of deep learning architectures.
The course will introduce the taxonomy of reinforcement learning by focusing on model-free value-based methods, transitioning to value function approximation and deep learning approaches, followed by novel policy-based methods using state-of-the-art architectures to tackle complex environments.
To conclude, a discussion on advanced topics, applications, and outlook of reinforcement learning will be provided.

title: DATS 6450 ‚Äì Reinforcement Learning
text:
Learning Outcomes

Implement Reinforcement Learning frameworks using NumPy and TensorFlow. 
Design decision-making systems using classical and deep learning architectures. 
Explain the Reinforcement Learning taxonomy. 
Identify Reinforcement Learning‚Äôs challenges, current research, and future outlook.

Function Approximation

Monte Carlo Tree Search

- OpenAI Gymansium Environment: Tic Tac Toe  - Model-based Reinforcement Learning  - Monte Carlo Tree Search  - AlphaGo  - MuZero


Oct 28, 2025
Conclusion




Dec 5, 2025
Final Project Submission

Average Learning Per Week



Students are expected to spend a minimum of 100 minutes of out-of-class work for every 50 minutes of direct instruction, for a minimum total of 2.5 hours a week. A 3-credit course should include 2.5 hours of direct instruction and a minimum of 5 hours of independent learning or 7.5 hours per week.

title: 1.1 Why should I study Reinforcement Learning?
text:
Advances in Artificial Intelligence
In essence, the AI model‚Äôs behavior closely mirrors human-like actions. This is expected, given its training on extensive datasets derived from human behavior. However, continued training on the same datasets will likely result in models that perform at a human-equivalent level. To achieve significant breakthroughs, we must explore learning methods that transcend typical human capabilities.
crumbs: 2¬† 1.1 Why should I study Reinforcement Learning?

title: 1.1 Why should I study Reinforcement Learning?
text:
June 2018: OpenAI introduces the Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT), laying the foundation for subsequent LLMs.
February 2019: OpenAI releases GPT-2, demonstrating significant improvements in text generation capabilities.
June 2020: GPT-3 is unveiled, featuring 175 billion parameters and showcasing advanced language understanding and generation.
January 2021: OpenAI announces DALL-E, a model capable of generating images from textual descriptions.
April 2022: DALL-E 2 is introduced, offering enhanced image resolution and greater realism in generated images.
November 2022: OpenAI releases ChatGPT, a conversational AI based on the GPT-3.5 architecture, enabling more interactive and contextually relevant dialogues.













At GWU, where minds aspire,  Reinforcement learners never tire  In search of policies, bold and bright,  They train their agents, day and night.   With Sutton, Barto as their guide,  They walk the path, rewards beside.  Exploring states with epsilon‚Äôs grace,  They find the optimal embrace.   Gridworlds vast, mazes deep,  In code they sow, in dreams they reap.  The future‚Äôs theirs, they push, they strive‚Äì  GWU‚Äôs learners, alive, alive!



Poem and images generated by Large Language Model: ChatGPT 3.5 & Diffusion Models: DALL-E, correspondingly.
crumbs: 2¬† 1.1 Why should I study Reinforcement Learning?

title: 1.1 Why should I study Reinforcement Learning?
text:
The Goal of Reinforcement Learning






Emergent Behavior



Reinforcement Learning is concerned with seeking emergent behavior, or behavior that goes beyond what people might do or think of. 


Ultimately, as scientists, we want to discover new solutions for a task so that when an agent, or decision-maker, is placed in a novel situation it can respond intelligently (Levine 2019).

Example: AlphaGO





AlphaGo Move 37



‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a human move. I‚Äôve never seen a human play this move.‚Äù ‚Äì Commentator on Move 37, AlphaGo (2017)




Example: Matrix Multiplication





Discovering faster matrix multiplication algorithms with reinforcement learning



‚ÄúTrained from scratch, AlphaTensor discovers matrix multiplication algorithms that are more efficient than existing human and computer-designed algorithms.‚Äù - Discovering faster matrix multiplication algorithms with reinforcement learning
crumbs: 2¬† 1.1 Why should I study Reinforcement Learning?

title: 1.2 What is Reinforcement Learning?
text:
Learning Optimal Sequential Decision-Making Under Uncertainty
Good news! We can sum up the core idea of Reinforcement Learning in just one powerful sentence (Brunskill 2022):
But what exactly does that mean? Let‚Äôs break it down!
crumbs: 3¬† 1.2 What is Reinforcement Learning?

title: 1.2 What is Reinforcement Learning?
text:
Learning
At its core, learning in Reinforcement Learning occurs through trial and error, where an agent refines its actions based on evaluative feedback from the environment.






Evaluative Feedback



Evaluative feedback indicates how good the action taken was, but not whether it was the best or the worst action. 

Intuition: Learning through experience









Learning to Walk








Ethics (Right vs.¬†Wrong)





Unlike both supervised/unsupervised learning which rely on instructive feedback through gradient based optimization.






Instructive Feedback



Instructive feedback indicates the correct action to take, independently of the action actually taken. 

Intuition: Learning through ground truth







Supervised/Unsupervised Learning



For example, supervised/unsupervised learning focus on identifying what makes an image a cheetah by learning patterns from a dataset of animal images. In contrast, Reinforcement Learning is about teaching a cheetah how to run by interacting with its environment (Lecture 10).



 ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs some examples (images), now learn patterns in these examples‚Ä¶‚Äù



 ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs an environment, now learn patterns by exploring it‚Ä¶‚Äù
crumbs: 3¬† 1.2 What is Reinforcement Learning?

title: 1.2 What is Reinforcement Learning?
text:
Optimal
The goal of Reinforcement Learning is to maximize rewards over time by finding the best possible strategy. This involves seeking:

A Maximized discounted sum of rewards, or goal \(G\).
Optimal Value Functions \(V^{*}\).
Optimal Action-Value Functions \(Q^{*}\).
Optimal Policies \(\pi^{*}\).
A Balance between exploration vs.¬†exploitation.
crumbs: 3¬† 1.2 What is Reinforcement Learning?

title: 1.2 What is Reinforcement Learning?
text:
Sequential Decision-Making
Unlike a one-time choice, Reinforcement Learning involves a chain of decisions where each action affects the next.




Markov Decision Process




\(\pi: S_{0}, A_{0}, R_{1}, S_{1}, A_{1}, R_{2}, ... , S_{T-1}, A_{T-1}, R_{T}\)


Markov Decision Process (MDP) is a formal framework for modeling decision-making.
The agent selects actions over multiple time steps, shaping its future states and rewards.
Each decision affects not only immediate rewards but also the trajectory of future outcomes.





Brunskill, Emma. 2022. ‚ÄúCS234: Reinforcement Learning - Lecture 1.‚Äù Course Lecture Slides, Stanford University. https://web.stanford.edu/class/cs234/slides/lecture1pre.pdf.
crumbs: 3¬† 1.2 What is Reinforcement Learning?

title: 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?
text:
Recommendation Systems
Reinforcement Learning powers modern recommendation systems by dynamically adapting to user preferences, optimizing content suggestions in platforms like Netflix, YouTube, and Spotify using techniques such as Multi-Armed Bandits (MAB).
crumbs: 4¬† 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?

title: 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?
text:
Trained using MAB (Lecture 2)
Link to Online Article
crumbs: 4¬† 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?

title: 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?
text:
Games
Reinforcement Learning has revolutionized gaming by enabling AI to master complex environments, from Atari classics to advanced strategy games, using deep learning techniques like Deep Q-Networks (DQN) to achieve superhuman performance.


Trained using DQN (Lecture 9)
Link to Research Paper
crumbs: 4¬† 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?

title: 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?
text:
Robotics
In robotics, Reinforcement Learning enables autonomous agents to learn complex motor skills, such as dexterous manipulation and locomotion, through continuous interaction and training with Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO).


Trained using PPO (Lecture 11)
Link to Blog
crumbs: 4¬† 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?

title: 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?
text:
Autonomous Vehicles
Self-driving cars rely on Reinforcement Learning to navigate complex environments, optimize decision-making, and improve safety, often incorporating PPO and deep learning to refine real-time control strategies.

   Partly trained using PPO (Lecture 11)
crumbs: 4¬† 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?

title: 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?
text:
Natural Language Processing
Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) enhances AI language models like ChatGPT, allowing them to refine responses based on user interactions and align better with human preferences.


Trained using PPO (Lecture 11)
Link to Research Paper
crumbs: 4¬† 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?

title: 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?
text:
Finance
In financial markets, RL is applied to portfolio optimization, algorithmic trading, and risk management, leveraging techniques like PPO to make data-driven investment decisions.


Trained using PPO (Lecture 11)
Link to Research Paper
crumbs: 4¬† 1.3 Where is Reinforcement Learning Applied?

title: Motivation
section: So why should I study Reinforcement Leanring?
text:
So why should I study Reinforcement Leanring?






Reinforcement Learning (RL) is not just another machine learning paradigm; it is a fundamental framework for decision-making, control, and optimizing sequential actions in uncertain environments. Studying RL enables us to: 
‚úÖ Understand Intelligence  ‚úÖ Develop Cutting-Edge AI  ‚úÖ Solve Real-World Problems  ‚úÖ Push Beyond Human Limits 
By studying RL, we gain the tools to create AI that learns, adapts, and innovates beyond predefined rules and static datasets. üöÄ

title: 1.1 Why should I study Reinforcement Learning?
section: So why should I study Reinforcement Learning?
text:
So why should I study Reinforcement Learning?
Reinforcement Learning (RL) is not just another machine learning paradigm; it is a fundamental framework for decision-making, control, and optimizing sequential actions in uncertain environments. Studying RL enables us to: 

‚úÖ Understand Intelligence  ‚úÖ Develop Cutting-Edge AI  ‚úÖ Solve Real-World Problems  ‚úÖ Push Beyond Human Limits 

By studying RL, we gain the tools to create AI that learns, adapts, and innovates beyond predefined rules and static datasets. üöÄ
